utterances.speaker: MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: All right. Good evening, everybody. I'm Martha MacCallum in New York. And this is THE STORY. Tonight, President Trump speaking about the very rapid progress on a COVID-19 vaccine that after the United States hit another grim milestone of 200,000 deaths. Today, we heard from doctors Fauci, Redfield and Giroir. Admiral Giroir will join us later on the show. So, stick around for that in just a few moments. This is what was said by the president just moments ago at the White House. Watch.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: Earlier this year, Johnson & Johnson anticipated that they would reach phase one trials by September. But due to our support under Operation Warp Speed, they reached phase three trials by September, far ahead of schedule. We encourage Americans to enroll in the vaccine trial.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So that obviously is very big news. And we're going to talk more about it in just a second. The other very big story tonight comes out of Kentucky, where the Attorney General Daniel Cameron, announced the findings of the grand jury in the Breonna Taylor case. One of the officers involved was indicted on charges of wanton endangerment for bullets that were fired from his weapon that went into the nearby apartment, not Taylor's apartment, but another apartment that night. So, the fact that the grand jury did not charge any of the three officers who exchanged fire in her apartment in her death has led to some difficult moments on the streets of Louisville tonight.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: There's a curfew there later tonight. The National Guard is on alert. The president was going to have a conversation with the governor there when he left the news conference today. This is Taylor family Attorney Ben Crump and Attorney General David Cameron earlier today. Watch.

utterances.speaker: BENJAMIN CRUMP, BREONNA TAYLOR'S ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: For 401 years, we have been dealing with systematic racism and oppression that finds police killing us outside the courtroom and the system killing us inside the courtroom.

utterances.speaker: DANIEL CAMERON, KENTUCKY ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.utterance: My heart breaks for the loss of Ms. Taylor. And I've said that repeatedly, my mother, if something was to happen to me, would find it very hard.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So emotional on this, but from the attorney general, national correspondent Matt Finn is live in Louisville tonight. Matt, good evening.

utterances.speaker: MATT FINN, NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Good evening, Martha. We're in the heart of downtown Louisville right now. This is Jefferson Park, which over the past weeks and months has served as ground zero, not only for a memorial for Breonna Taylor, but also for demonstrators. Right now, hundreds, maybe a thousand demonstrators were out. There's actually some small fires burning here right now. People have been chanting Black Lives Matter chants and profanities against police. It looks like this group is likely going to march. They've already kind of moved around a little bit. We'll keep you updated on that. Of course, the big news this evening, none of the three officers involved in the shooting death of Breonna Taylor were charged with murder. One former officer, Detective Brett Hankinson, was charged with three counts of wanton endangerment, a much lesser charge. People here are not happy with that decision and protesters are out in the streets. Kentucky's Attorney General, Daniel Cameron, also revealing some key findings of his office's investigation. Cameron says evidence shows that the officers knocked and denounced at Breonna Taylor's apartment. It was not a no-knock warrant. The attorney general says that was corroborated by an independent witness. The Kentucky Attorney General's office also concluding that two out of three officers involved in Taylor's shooting death were authorized to use force because they were fired at first by Breonna Taylor's boyfriend, Kenneth Walker. Police say, Kenneth Walker told police he fired first because he thought intruders were breaking in. Breonna Taylor's family and attorney had been demanding that all of the officers get at least second-degree manslaughter. That has not happened. And Kentucky's Attorney General says he is a black man speaking on behalf of the entire investigation, as a black man he understands how painful this is for the black community. He says twice today that criminal law is not always meant to respond to what he calls a tragedy. He also says, representatives of his office have taken a lot of criticism and scrutiny. He says that scrutiny in many ways was misplaced because there was not a day that people in his office didn't go to sleep thinking about this case. Also, the attorney general today did not reveal the makeup of that grand jury, the age and race of the grand jury. He says this case is too sensitive right now to reveal that. Also, he says he's launching a task force to investigate the process of obtaining a search warrant here in Kentucky. And again Martha, there's a couple of fires just kind of burning out of control right now.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Matt Finn, thank you very much. We'll head back there in a little while. I'm joined now by Kentucky Senator Rand Paul. Senator, thank you very much for being here tonight. I mean, Breonna Taylor was not the subject of an investigation when these detectives came to the apartment. She was with her boyfriend. They had been looking into possible drug connections with her former boyfriend who lives several miles away. What - how does this decision sit with you tonight, Senator?

utterances.speaker: SEN. RAND PAUL (R-KY)
utterances.utterance: Well, I've been a longtime advocate of getting rid of no-knock raids. I know in your lead up to this; they say it wasn't necessarily a no-knock raid. However, it's a high-risk raid going in after midnight looking for possession of drugs. And I think it's not worth losing the life of a police officer or someone inside the house. So, I'm just not in favor of doing this in search of drug possession. I don't think it's worth the loss of life. With regard to Louisville, though, I'm kind of saddened to see the fires. I hope we can begin to heal on this. I've been calling for weeks for the National Guard to be out. I think the governor has not taken that seriously. I hope there will be enough National Guard to prevent the destruction downtown in Louisville. It's a great city. And I hope it doesn't catch on fire more than what we see so far.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I mean, the way that the Attorney General Daniel Cameron laid out the findings and it's worth reiterating that this is the decision of the grand jury. This is not the decision of the attorney general. They investigated. They brought forth the information before this grand jury. The FBI also did an investigation and those findings were made available to this grand jury. But what do you say to people in Louisville tonight who are upset with what even led up to them being at that apartment and feel that it was a situation that got out of control and that there's nothing being done to fix that? I know you've tried to address that, but what would you say to them tonight to these people who are obviously very upset?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: I think this is a bad situation where we put police into a bad situation and also the people on the other side of the door, Breonna Taylor, and her boyfriend in a bad situation. The best way to do this is to reform the law. So, Louisville has banned no knock raids. Now they're looking at how this warrant was obtained. I've introduced federal legislation also to get rid of no-knock raids to try to prevent some tragedy like this from happening again. So, I think we are responding in a way. The specific details, I can't judge guilt or innocence. And ultimately, this isn't the end. This is the beginning. A jury will have to decide that. But those details are best left to a jury without politicians and everybody else weighing in on guilt or innocence. But I don't want this to happen again. And I am working hard to try to make sure these are federal law; local law prevents this from happening.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: We remember when you were accosted by protesters in the street who wanted you to chant her name, and they were obviously not aware of the work that you had been doing on behalf of these no knock raids on the Breonna Taylor Act, which you initiated. I want to ask you a little bit about COVID and the hearings on the Hill today, which you were part of. This is an exchange that you had with Dr. Fauci.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: How can we possibly be jumping up and down and saying, Governor Cuomo did a great job, he had the worst death rate in the world?

utterances.speaker: DR. ANTHONY FAUCI, DIRECTOR, NIAID
utterances.utterance: No, you misconstrued that, Senator, and you've done that repetitively in the past because they are looking at the guidelines that we have put together or they've developed enough community immunity. I challenged that, Senator, because this happens with Senator Rand all the time, that in New York it's about 22 percent. If you believe 22 percent is herd immunity, I believe you're alone in that.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, you went after him on the subject of Governor Cuomo and the record in New York, which I think a lot of New Yorkers can understand. You also went after him on this question as a doctor on how - what percentage does connote herd immunity and you guys went back and forth on it. Tell me about that.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: Well, the facts are the facts from the Johns Hopkins website, which is esteemed. And people say these are the facts. The highest death rate in the world is in New York. 1700 deaths per million. The U.S. average about 500. The average are actually about 600 now. The average in Sweden, about 570. But on the question of herd immunity, they're dismissive of this. But I'm sending over to Dr. Fauci, so he can read a little bit on this in Science magazine, in August, three mathematicians came out with the idea that because an infection - transmission of infections and immunity seem to be concentrated in younger people, they seem to catch this faster and be more active and out in public more than it actually skews the formulas on herd immunity and would allow herd immunity at a much lower rate. The other thing from the John Hopkins website, you see is New York's having no new incidents and no new deaths. Now he wants to say, oh, it's because everybody's washing their hands. I don't believe that. I think they're washing their hands in April, we still had all these deaths. So, there's something going on and I can't say with certainty, but over the next couple of months, if there is no significant surge again, without a vaccine in New York, it will look like herd immunity. That's what it looks like in Sweden right now. And it looks like this around the world when people have had a significant surge, they're not getting a second surge. And there are mathematicians who have looked at the formula on herd immunity in the August edition of Science Journal. And they actually say, you know what, herd immunity may come much lower than some of these experts think.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I think it's fascinating and I think only time will really tell. I did read that study as well. Before I let you go, can you give us your thoughts on the Hunter Biden investigation? There was a preliminary report on the findings, and it didn't seem to find anything that connected him to anything illegal.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know. I think riding on Air Force Two and doing business is illegal. I think that is against the law and probably a felony. I think it's illegal to take money from a Russian politician's wife. $3.5 million, was it reported accurately? I think the only way to determine the actual legality of this is to have it referred to the Department of Justice. So, I'm going to send the report over. I don't know if the whole committee will vote for it, but I'm sending the report tomorrow to the Department of Justice and we're asking for a criminal referral. We want to see - if there's a criminal investigation that's justified, here is this evidence, look at it, and then you're the lawyers for the government. You decide if you have enough to prosecute. But I think we should refer this for a criminal investigation.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. We've got to leave it there. Senator, thank you for coming on tonight. Good to see you, sir.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, we will go back to the scene in Louisville later in the hour. But first, President Trump making a major announcement on the vaccine moments ago as top health officials defend their response to the virus on Capitol Hill following the grim milestone of 200,000 lives in the United States. Admiral Brett Giroir, White House Coronavirus testing czar, is joining me next. Stick around. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We want to have people not get sick. The vaccine is very important. It's the final step. I believe it's going to be the final step.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Today, my administration announced that we are awarding $200 million of CARES Act funding to all 50 states to prepare to distribute the vaccine to high risk residents and we want to do that the instant it is approved.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Good timeline on that. A short time ago, President Trump briefed the nation on the race for a COVID-19 vaccine, saying that his administration is preparing for the most vulnerable Americans, as you heard him say right there, to be vaccinated as soon as possible. So that announcement comes the day after the United States surpassed 200,000 deaths. Today, top health officials, including my next guest were on Capitol Hill to answer for the handling of the pandemic. Senator Murray challenged Dr. Giroir on the changing directives from the CDC.

utterances.speaker: SEN. PATTY MURRAY (D-WA)
utterances.utterance: State health departments recommend testing for asymptomatic people. I want to ask you; on what scientific basis did members of the task force take a different position?

utterances.speaker: ADM BRETT GIROIR, WHITE HOUSE CORONAVIRUS TASK FORCE
utterances.utterance: Unequivocally, it did not recommend against testing asymptomatic individuals. It was widely misinterpreted. It was widely misrepresented.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Admiral Brett Giroir, testing czar for the White House Coronavirus Task Force joins me now. Admiral, thank you very much for being here tonight. There have been a number of different events where the CDC guidance has been changed, in the next 24, 48 hours. And I think that has led to a lot of head scratching and people wondering what's going on with that. There was a story that said that basically that the guidelines that had been put together were too strict. They started calling for more than six feet and social distance. And the report said that the White House basically shot it down and said this isn't going out. And then we saw the backpedaling. Can you clarify that?

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: So, thank you for having me on. And the first thing with the testing guidance, I did mean what I said to Senator Murray today, that the CDC's guidance never said don't test asymptomatic individuals. In fact, we're doing everything we can to improve testing of asymptomatic individuals. But it's important to have that with some degree of public health knowledge, because if you test negative today, it doesn't mean you won't be negative tomorrow. And so there really was not a reversal in that guidelines, it was a clarification--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: With that because the language did change. I mean, originally it said--

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: That the suggestion was that if you don't have symptoms, you don't have to get tested. So, what changed?

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: It never said that. It said that. And again, this is CDC guidance that was generated by the CDC. It said that you may not necessarily need to be tested. So, look, Martha, if I just got exposed and I went and isolated in my apartment for 14 days, I didn't see anyone. I stayed there. Do I need a test? I really don't need a test. I'm not going to expose anyone. I'm not sick. But what we saw was the guidance was misinterpreted. It was misrepresented. And we saw all kinds of ill activity stemming from that. The CDC Director, Dr. Redfield, clarified it the next day. And as it kept getting misrepresented and it started propagating, he decided to update the guidance and clarified even more. There's nothing more than that.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. The other issue was the issue of social distance that maybe six feet was more necessary and that it could or could not be spread through aerosols. I mean, the bottom line is, have you ever been in a situation where you felt that the White House was saying to your task force, no, that we don't like that, it's not going to go over well, it's going to prevent some of the reopening that we need to see. Have you ever been in that situation?

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: No, I really have not been in that situation, the task force meetings are very interactive, there's a lot of discussion and we talk about the implications of policies. But the dock, the dock group meets frequently. We pass along guidance. We talk about the implications of it. We've never been pressured. I've never been told by the president to stop testing or to change a guidance or to alter the facts. It just doesn't happen like that. Every task force meeting opens with Dr. Birx looking at all the evidence. What is the epidemiology? It's typically followed by Dr. Fauci. And then it goes through all the different docs and policy areas. So, it's very evidence based, very data driven. I don't feel pressured. And none of us on the task force, none of the docs on that task force would bow to pressure. We have long careers again be the truth is, is the most important--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Understood, which we respect, of course. This is another exchange from today from Dr. Fauci. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: FAUCI
utterances.utterance: It's very disrespectful to me because I'm in my 70s. But it isn't just the elderly and those with underlying conditions because it can be serious in young people.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Sorry, that was from an interview, obviously. But what he was referring to, was the president's claim at the rally the other night where he said that it affects elderly people, people with heart problems. And it said nobody like nobody young below the age of 18, they have a strong immune system. And that that is actually what Dr. Fauci was referring to. Where do you stand on that divide?

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: Well, it's not where I stand. It's what the evidence shows. And clearly, elderly individuals are at very high risk. 80 percent of a mortality is over age 65. We know that racial and ethnic minorities are five times more likely to be in hospitals. Those who are under 18, under 21 are very unlikely to have a serious consequence--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: We have pointed that out many times. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: But they can still be hospitalized and there have been deaths.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I think that was the--

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: We have to be careful with our children as well--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: We heard Dr. Fauci today talking about lingering effects and heart conditions and inflammation around the heart. How big a concern is that? Is that a very rare situation or is it a big concern?

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: It is a legitimate and a serious concern. We don't know how many people it happens in. Coming to say, Martha, even after influenza or other summertime viruses, we can see this kind of heart inflammation. So, this is not something entirely new. It's something that we need to look for. And we do need to follow it. It can resolve completely, or it could lead to arrhythmias or poor heart function. So, we do need to follow it. We need to get more data. This is a brand-new virus, so we really have to follow it closely, as Dr. Fauci said today.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. Admiral, thank you.

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Very good to have you here tonight. Thanks for answering the questions.

utterances.speaker: GIROIR
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All the best. So, coming up, we will take you back to Louisville. We have seen so many cities have the kind of violence that has happened in some of these situations under racial tension. So, Portland, of course, has seen months of protests, calls to defund the police. And after the city disbanded their gun violence reduction team, as they called it, now they're seeing a surge in shootings and homicides. Now, the mayor says maybe we should put that group back. Portland Police Union President Daryl Turner responds after this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Follow the God, and you will see justice. But it is up to--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, that is the scene tonight 7:28 Eastern Time in New York City, protesters gathering in response to the grand jury decision to charge one of the officers involved in the Breonna Taylor case. In Portland, one person was shot outside a protest last night. There has been a surge of shootings there in recent months, up nearly 200 percent in July and August from the year before, and already doubling in the month of September. So that spike comes after Portland's mayor, Ted Wheeler, who's also the police commissioner, disbanded their city's task force team in charge of keeping gun violence down in the city. They also slashed the budget of the police by $15 million. So then after those two actions, you have seen a surge in violence. So, the president of the Portland Police Association, Daryl Turner, joins me now. Mr. Turner, thank you very much for being here. So, is it true that now Mayor Wheeler says that he might need to put something along the lines of that force back in place to stop people from getting shot in the streets in Portland?

utterances.speaker: DARYL TURNER, PRESIDENT, PORTLAND POLICE ASSOCIATION
utterances.utterance: Well, he realizes that it was a mistake. Defunding the police is not a solution. It's a political stunt. It is - Portland police officers and all police officers respond to calls to service. They respond to calls no matter what your race, creed, culture, religion, sexual orientation, or gender is. And so, in a city of Portland, July 1st, they disbanded our gun violence reduction team whose presence in the nation for the work that they did. And immediately shootings went up. Homicides went up over higher than it's ever been in a 30-year period for the month of July. August was also a record month, and September is becoming another record month for shooting.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, who are the victims of those crimes and, you know, what do you say to the people in those neighborhoods who are now afraid to go out of their house or they are afraid that bullets might come actually into their house?

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Well, what you have to do is you look at the dynamics of it. Most of the people affected are people of color. In one shooting in one neighborhood 150 rounds were fired. One hundred fifty rounds indiscriminately in neighborhoods in the houses in the places where people live, where people play, where people want to raise their children and families. That is unacceptable.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I just want to play a sound bite for you. This is Kamala Harris who of course is running for the vice presidency. She's been very outspoken on reimagining police departments as something she feels strongly about in this country and she also commented today on the Breonna Taylor outcome. Here she is on Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), VICE PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Let's talk about America's failure when it comes to understanding how you create safe communities. It is outdated, it is a wrongheaded thinking to think that the only way you are going to get communities to be safe is to put more police officer officers on the street. What we have to do and what we will do is reimagine public safety. You want a safe community; you have to invest in the health and well-being of that community.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: She actually said the exact opposite when she was attorney general in California, she said there needed to be more police on the street so now she has a very different take. I'm curious, you know, what your thoughts on what you had to say, sir.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Well, anyone who says anything about defunding the police, it's just a political stunt. Politicians bent on power and perpetrate misinformation and untruths are just as guilty as using their privilege to hijack this movement, the movement of racial equity, the movement of social justice are the rioters who are committing violent acts, burning and looting and causing chaos in the streets.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Before I let you go, I just want to ask if you have a comment on the outcome on the Breonna Taylor case and those detectives involved.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: I haven't read enough to actually comment on that but I will tell you this. In the city of Portland, we are -- we have put forward a petition. I'm asking everyone watching to go to protect https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=http-3A__portland.org&d=DwICAg&c=cnx1hdOQtepEQkpermZGwQ&r=66NL-BOo471AGSm_KnwRE_qfHEjM19jJhbDYidH1S1U&m=UFlrDKvQQ7WphzktExQmzTgD7O4RpwPGhJRWzLAA08Y&s=hycau1JjX_DnEBIoeStojAxiMwIYSla3DRSzNM3P0_A&e=Â  to sign a petition to protect Portland, to protect our officers, to protect our communities. I would hope everybody could go to that and give us a hand in doing that and so that we don't have the outcomes like we had in Kentucky with Breonna Taylor and other places so that we can train our police officers better, so that we can hire better police officers and more police officers to be proactive.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Sir, thank you. Daryl Turner, president of the Portland Police Association. Thank you very much for being here tonight.

utterances.speaker: TURNER
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, Joe Biden is back on the campaign trail today hosting an economic summit for black voters in North Carolina as President Trump and Republicans have forged ahead to fill the Supreme Court vacancy. We are going to talk to the Republican Senator Thom Tillis of North Carolina and then Democrat Senator Chris Coons. Both of them are on the very important judiciary committee that will handle these hearings. We'll talk to them, next.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, Joe Biden is back on the campaign trail today, this time he was traveling to the battleground state of North Carolina. And there he held a black economic summit, it was called. It is a key state obviously in 2020. The New York Times even going so far as to put this headline. The White House, Senate and Supreme Court could all hinge on North Carolina. Now back in 2016, President Trump won the state's 15 electoral votes, beating Hillary Clinton by more than three, now Joe Biden and the president are neck and neck essentially when you go for the margin of error in the state of North Carolina. Now the former vice president's trip comes of course amid the looming Supreme Court showdown which could have a significant impact on this election. And earlier today Joe Biden expressed his hope that some Republican senators would still come out to oppose filling that seat.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: There's two people have announced, had the guts to announce that they would wait until the election is over, they shouldn't vote until then. If two others stand up and do the right thing, then it'll be put off until the election. If he wins, then he gets to go forward with the nominee that he wants to name. And if he loses, then I get to make that pick. But I won't be able to make that pick until January 21st.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: OK. Here now, Senate Republicans Senator Thom Tillis of North Carolina, a member of the Senate judiciary committee. Senator, good to have you with us tonight. Thank you for being here.

utterances.speaker: SEN. THOM TILLIS (R-NC)
utterances.utterance: Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, there's a lot of looking back at this point, this is a flashback to what you said when Merrick Garland was nominated by President Obama in 2016.

utterances.speaker: TILLIS
utterances.utterance: The campaign is already underway. It is essential to the institution of the Senate and to the very health of our republic not to launch our nation into a partisan divisive confirmation battle during the very same time the American people are casting ballots to elect our next president.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: OK. So, you're on record saying that then, that was in February of 2016. So, what do you say now, Senator?

utterances.speaker: TILLIS
utterances.utterance: We had a lame duck president and a divided government. We have Donald Trump who has already published a list of nominees that he would put forth, he's running for re-election and I believe he is going to win. If Joe Biden wants to make this about the Supreme Court, why doesn't he unmask his list of liberal activist judges that we know he's going to put forward because that's how he got the nomination? That would be the easiest thing to let the American people decide the future of the Supreme Court. We're going to move forward with his nomination and we're going to move forward with the confirmation.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, you are down by about four points in the polls, the average of polls right now. According to reports there's about 12 percent undecided votes in North Carolina. So, you're, in one sense, making a bet that taking this stance and agreeing that we should go ahead with the Supreme Court vacancy is going to persuade some of those voters?

utterances.speaker: TILLIS
utterances.utterance: I think it's any number of things. It's the violence that we are seeing in our city, it's not going to be any one thing, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TILLIS
utterances.utterance: I think the Supreme Court will play a role, the violence that we are seeing in the city, the protesters who came to my house before sunrise yesterday and they are antifa garb, the American people are tired of all of that. And if Joe Biden takes that extra step of telling us who he would nominate, I think it will be a game set match.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, do you agree that North Carolina is that pivotal that it can be the deciding state, the Senate and the Supreme Court potentially?

utterances.speaker: TILLIS
utterances.utterance: Well, there's no doubt that it will be. It will -- the path to the White House and the path to keeping the Senate goes to North Carolina. Our race is critical I would tell you, the polls, I'm feeling better about the polls this cycle than I did in 2014. We weren't that well off. At the end of the day we win on our track record and we win on the work that President Trump and I have done in the U.S. Senate.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. Senator Thom Tillis, thank you very much, sir. Good to have you with us tonight.

utterances.speaker: TILLIS
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Martha

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, also here tonight, Democrat Senator Chris Coons, also a member of the very important Senate judiciary committee. They've got their work cut out for them. Senator Coons, thank you very much. Good to have you with us tonight.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHRIS COONS (D-DE)
utterances.utterance: Great to be with you again, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, let's put a show on the other foot for a moment here. Let's assume that Hillary Clinton had won the election that right now she is president of the United States, and that just for the sake of argument President Trump is a candidate again and he has decided to run against her. Judge Ginsburg passes away on September 18th --

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: That's quite a hypothetical, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Judge Ginsburg passes away on September 18th and Hillary Clinton is the president. And she risks losing the presidency, would you be encouraging her to go ahead and try to fill that seat before the election?

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: Well, two things. I would be pointing out to her that it's never happened that this close to an election, just 41 days before an election when half of the states in our country are already voting for president, that a president has moved forward with filling that seat. President Abraham Lincoln is one of just two that had a vacancy this close to the election and he declined to fill that seat. But I would also tell her that whoever that successor is, is going to preside over some very important decisions. As you know just a week after the election, the Supreme Court will hear the Affordable Care Act case and nothing, nothing could more put Ginsburg's -- excuse me -- Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's legacy on the record like the Affordable Care Act.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: OK. So that sounds like you would be convincing her to go ahead, because there is so much at stake. That sounds like you would convince her to go ahead because there is so much at stake. I repeat myself.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: I just left the steps of the Supreme Court where I paid my respects to Justice Ginsburg. She was a fighter for gender equity and the Affordable Care Act protects every woman in America against discrimination based on being a woman. And in the middle of a pandemic, President Trump and the 18 states that are suing in the Supreme Court are trying to take away healthcare protections from half of all Americans.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. So, I'm going to take that as an argument --

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: That's what's on the ballot and I think that's significant.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: -- that you would make to a president Hillary Clinton that it was a desperate situation and she should fill that seat if she had the ability to do so. I want to ask you about, you know, there's already, we don't know who the nominee is going to be, but Amy Coney Barrett's name is definitely at the top of the list it would appear. We know that the president is meeting with Barbara Lagoa on Friday as well. You are a Christian man, you are a graduate of Yale Divinity School, do you believe that a person's faith is fair game for questions in these hearings?

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: There is no and should be no religious test for serving in the United States, that's in our Constitution. And I think we should conduct our questioning of nominees in front of us in a respectful but appropriate way as we can. My concern here is that we shouldn't be moving forward with hearings at all, and so frankly I'm more concerned with the damage that racing through a partisan confirmation just 41 days before the election will do to the court, to our Senate, and to our country. What I hear from Delawareans, Martha, is if we've still got 40 days why aren't we moving ahead with the COVID relief package? Several major CEOs just today came out and said, dedicate your time to a COVID relief package to those negotiations?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, I think a lot of people would love to see that, and a lot of people know that --

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: Me too.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: -- there are Republicans and Democrats who agree on quite a bit in the middle ground --

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: -- and would love to see that accomplished as well. But I want to go back to this question of faith in these hearings, because I think it is likely to come up. Because Senator Feinstein when she was speaking with Judge Barrett in the past, she brought up her Catholicism and she said that she was -- that the dogma lived deeply within her and she looked very concerned about that. She is the ranking Democrat member on your committee. Do you have confidence that she is not going to raise that, as you just said, it should not be a factor this time around?

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: Look, I have a lot of respect for Senator Feinstein and for her leadership of our caucus on the -- our committee. I'm going to be urging my colleagues to first make it clear, Democrats to Republicans, as Joe Biden did in the campaign remarks that you just played it, that we should be stepping back from this abyss. That we shouldn't be having these confirmation hearings just two weeks from now, that doesn't give us enough time to thoroughly research the opinions, the writings of whoever might be nominated. That's why we shouldn't be racing ahead in this very limited period of time. But in general, as you know, Martha, I'm someone who as the co-chair of the National Prayer Breakfast has tried to bring forward a respectful tone here in Washington, and our deliberations at all times, that's not always easy in this divided Congress in this divided nation. But I think moving ahead with this confirmation this close to the election in direct violation of the president set by the majority four years ago will simply further divide us.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. I want to ask you one more thing before I go. Because you have called for an investigation into the John Durham investigation, which I would point out is an investigation into the investigation, into the Russia issue, which the Mueller team investigated for two years. And that does raise some questions, especially since we don't even have a Durham report yet to criticize or to potentially investigate.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: That's a lot of investigations.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: It sure it.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: My point simply was that, the Inspector General, Horowitz, has already conducted a relevant and thorough investigation. Why is this additional Durham investigation necessary? That was my point.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right. I'm going to leave it there. Thank you very much, Senator.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Good to have you with us as always.

utterances.speaker: COONS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Thank you for coming tonight. All right. So, going back and forth between the very big stories that we are watching this evening. This is the scene on Black Lives Matter plaza I believe is where they are in Washington, D.C. this evening. This is an area and has seen a lot of gatherings over the course of the last several months and it was an area where there was also some breaking up windows and things along those lines a while back. So, we are watching all these situations across the country. The reaction to this very significant decision in the Breonna Taylor case, we are going to have more on that when we come back.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: We are keeping an eye on increasing protest this evening in large cities across the country, you can see them in these four live shots that we have after the grand jury in Louisville, Kentucky decided not to charge the police officers there with the death of Breonna Taylor. One of the three detectives involved in this case was indicted on three counts of wanton endangerment, but that had to do with the firing of his weapon into a nearby apartment in the midst of the chaos that wasn't suing at Taylor's apartment. In Louisville about one hour from now, a country -- countywide, I should say, curfew will go into effect and that is where Jeff Paul joins us tonight on the street there. Good evening, Jeff.

utterances.speaker: JEFF PAUL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Hi, Martha. Getting a little hectic here in downtown Louisville after a pretty much peaceful day of protest. You can see a trash can has been set on fire out here with some things thrown in here. We've seen a few others set on fire. This is probably the largest one, but really the only main, sort of, we want to call it property damage that we have seen. Firework there that just exploded. And that's something we see from time to time, there it is protest that use fireworks. I'm pretty sure that was a firework, I don't think that was a bomb of any kind of sort but nonetheless, you never know what's going to happen out of this protest. And just to kind of rerack what happened today. That decision came down and after a few hours of people marching in the streets the police started pushing some of the people who were out here back. But they are back in downtown and you can see there's a few fires going right now. And as always with fires, you never know what's in it. And in this -- in this situation it looks like there was a firework. You know, the police have just showed up. Martha?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: All right, Jeff Paul, somebody putting an incendiary into a garbage can on the street there and it exploded just a few feet of way from where Jeff is covering the story. He has covered a lot of the stories over the course of the summer. And, you know, Jeff, can you give me any sense of who is around you and how organized this group is?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's really hard to tell, and you know, people obviously very spirited about what's going on out here. We just had an explosion actually, so from one thing to another you have an explosion and you have people out here singing Breonna Taylor's name. Yes, it's hard to tell really how organized it is right now, especially with some of these fires that have been lit here. I don't think the people who are down here to memorialize Breonna Taylor were exactly involved in that sort of behavior. That's not what we saw with the people who are passionately marching throughout the street. But nonetheless, when it gets dark that's when you really start to see some of this kind of behavior happening and as we get closer to that curfew, that 9 p.m. curfew, we might see some more of it. Martha?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Obviously, that is what we have seen, the implementation of curfews after dark to try to calm things down and that is still an hour away from kicking into effect. What is the police presence there, Jeff, in terms of implanting that in an hour and any way of telling whether or not they are going to be able to do that, whether or not people will cooperate?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: It's really hard to tell because when you walk down here you have police on the perimeters. Like if you take a look over here you can see there's some red and blue flashing lights. Just up into the distance, they have some of these dump trucks that are set up here to stop cars from coming down here. But if you take a look where most of these protests have started, this is Jefferson Square Park and these fires are burning now, I don't see one police officer inside. That's not saying they're not in the area and they're not -- just letting that kind of burn out and fizzle out. But you get a little outside and you start getting closer to like, the mayor's house or some of the bigger buildings, that's where you really start to see the police presence.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: yes. Did they stop, when I heard you on earlier today, Jeff, you were saying that the protests which we saw in the afternoon after the decision was moving towards the mayor's house. Did that happened, did they go down there? Was that all -- did that all go peacefully?

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, they marched for about three, three and a half miles and we were right there with them. And once they got about a half a mile away from the mayor's house, that's when police just sort of put their stakes in the ground and said you can't get any closer. And the police then started pushing them back. The majority of the protesters ended up moving back. But if you kind of stayed back and you saw probably about a dozen people who ended up with zip ties in their arms behind their back and they were taken off in process. But after that that was really the main clash between police and protesters. Since then we really haven't seen anything else other than these fires down here and the occasional person just kind of doing a burnout with the motorcycle or something like that.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: It's just remarkable how many cities we have seen. It's like, you almost get used to seeing fires in American cities and we've witnessed so much of it and you've covered so much of it for us the course of the summer. Thank you very much. Good to see you tonight. Jeff Paul, thank you.

utterances.speaker: PAUL
utterances.utterance: You bet.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: I want to bring in now the civil rights attorney Daryl Washington, he works alongside ben Crump, the attorney for the family of Breonna Taylor as the attorney for the family of Botham Jean as well, an African-American man who was murdered by an off-duty police officer back in 2019. Sir, thank you very much, Mr. Washington. Glad to have you with us this evening.

utterances.speaker: DARYL WASHINGTON, CIVIL RIGHTS ATTORNEY
utterances.utterance: Thank you for having me, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, you know, in the other case that I mentioned of Botham Jean, I believe that police officer went to prison. Correct?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: That is not the outcome that we saw today. Tell me your thoughts on this decision.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: You know, when the decision came down, we were holding hope and thinking that perhaps there was going to be some responsibility placed on these officers for the death of Breonna Taylor. But when we heard the decision being read out to the public it was quite disappointing because what we have now is, no one is going to be held responsible for the death of Breonna Taylor. And I think that's why we've seen the public outcry in Louisville and that's why I think we've been hearing the disappointment being raised by people throughout this country.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes. You know, there are two aspects in this case in a way that I have heard discussed today. One is what happened before the police officers even showed up at Breonna Taylor's apartment, why they were there, and the warrant, and you know, whether it was not no knock or not announced. Then you have what happened after they burst down that door to her apartment. And the finding as Daniel Cameron presented it, the attorney general, was that the fatal bullet that struck Breonna Taylor was in -- was fired in self-defense because her boyfriend had fired his gun, his weapon first. That was the finding of the grand jury. What do you -- what do you say to that? I mean, a grand jury evaluated all this evidence and that's what they found.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: One of the things, Martha, that we have big problems with, obviously what goes on in a grand jury proceeding is secret so we really don't know how a case is presented to the grand jury. We also know that these no-knock warrants have been very dangerous procedures. There is a lot of controversy because in one instance we are hearing that it was being executed as a no-knock warrants and in another instance, we are hearing that it was being executed as a knock and announce. So, there are lots of facts in this case that are still sketchy, there are a number of witnesses from my understanding who said that they did not hear the police officer announce themselves.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes, I hear that too.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: So, with the disputes that we have with these facts and just a testimony of Mr. Walker himself, we just felt that there was just enough evidence that was presented to make a jury, to have a jury decide this case and not be stopped at the grand jury level.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: Yes. We saw in the Rodney King case that at the federal level later on they did find, they did press and guilty charges in that case. Daryl Washington, thank you very much. As we watch these scenes tonight, we are grateful for your input. Thank you, sir. Good to have you with us.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: So, in the latest of the -- in the latest episode, I should say, of the "Untold Story" podcast I spoke with Henry McMaster, the president's former national security advisor. You saw the short version of it the other night but it was a very interesting conversation that I had with him and that podcast is going to be available tomorrow. And that is THE STORY on a busy September 23rd tonight. We'll see you tomorrow night. THE STORY will go on and we'll be here to cover it with you. Have a great night, everybody. Good night.
